title: Benefits of a ketogenic diet for an otherwise healthy person
content: Dom and Bob discuss the benefits of a ketogenic diet for an otherwise healthy person.

title: Ketogenic diet and the microbiome
content: Dom and Bob discuss the impact of the ketogenic diet on the microbiome.

title: Impact of fasted-state training on strength and performance
content: Dom and Bob discuss the impact of fasted-state training on strength and performance.

title: Is it possible to build muscle on a ketogenic diet?
content: Dom and Bob discuss whether it is possible to build muscle on a ketogenic diet.

title: Cardio Exercise
content: Dom mentions that he likes to do cardio exercise on a stationary bike or a rowing machine. He also talks about the benefits of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) for cardiovascular health.

title: Training Recovery
content: Peter and Dom discuss various protocols for recovering from hard training sessions, including the use of sauna, cold exposure, and supplements like magnesium and omega-3 fatty acids.

title: Fasting, Time-Restricted Eating, and Sleep
content: Dom shares his personal approach to fasting, time-restricted eating, and sleep, which includes a 16:8 fasting schedule and prioritizing sleep hygiene.

title: Training and Nutrition Resources
content: Dom mentions several people, books, and other resources that have shaped his training and nutrition philosophy, including Tim Ferriss, Gary Taubes, and Dr. Rhonda Patrick.

title: NASA Extreme Environment Mission Operations research
content: This project is evaluating the effects of hyperbaric environments, extreme environments on human physiology. They now have an IRB protocol for cognitive function, body composition, gut microbiome, sleep, heart rate variability, and stress.

title: Effects of ketones on cancer cachexia
content: They are looking at the effects of ketones on mitigating cancer cachexia and wasting associated with metastatic cancer. Dom just published a manuscript.

title: Metabolic therapies for various genetic diseases
content: They are developing ketone metabolic therapies as a means to treat these diseases not only from a metabolic perspective, but as a means to influence epigenetic pathways that may be used to treat the disease. Ketones may be a form of metabolic “epigenetic therapy” for genetic disorders like Kabuki syndrome.

title: Benefits of a ketogenic diet for an otherwise healthy person
content: The main benefit is that it promotes metabolic flexibility. Ketosis (and/or fasting) activates a genetic program that allows you to burn fat and make ketones more efficiently. It may take some time, but you have an innate ability to be metabolically flexible, so the more you do intermittent ketosis (or fasting), the more benefits you derive from it over time.

title: Glucose-ketone index and insulin suppression
content: The thing to target would be the glucose-ketone index. For example, you could restrict calories by 50% on a ketogenic diet and do that for six days a month and achieve, a glucose-ketone index between 1 and 2. Insulin suppression also occurs. Doing a restricted ketogenic diet combined that with time-restricted feeding, you’re hitting all the major drivers of the benefits that you’d get from fasting such as suppressed mTOR, suppressed insulin. It’s also probably stimulating autophagy.

title: Book recommendations for getting knowledgeable on the ketogenic diet
content: General info: The Ketogenic Bible—comprehensive overview of the ketogenic diet and recipes. For the athlete: The Art and Science of Low Carbohydrate Performance by Jeff Volek and Stephen Phinney – “book that really influenced me”. For the layman: Keto Answers—great book for the layman, defines modified ketogenic diet, recipes, tips, troubleshooting, etc. Clinical info: Ketogenic Diet and Metabolic Therapies—for listeners that are interested in the science. The Ketogenic and Modified Atkins Diets, 6th Edition: Treatments for Epilepsy and Other Disorders by Dr. Eric Kossoff – for those interested in a modified ketogenic approach from a clinical perspective. For Alzheimer’s: Complete Book of Ketones.

title: Best devices for measuring ketones
content: The Siemens Multistix SG is pretty good for a “yes or no” if you’re in ketosis. Precision Xtra is a blood test.

title: Methods of Measuring Ketones
content: There are several methods of measuring ketones, including blood testing with the Precision Xtra and Keto-Mojo, and breath acetone testing with the BioSense Breath Ketone Analyzer. Breath acetone is a strong indicator of fat oxidation, but it may not be accurate if you have had alcohol, a meal, or even chewing gum prior to the test. Blood testing is more reliable, but may measure slightly lower than an official lab test. When in ketosis, beta-hydroxybutyrate rises, and so does acetoacetate, which can spontaneously decarboxylate into acetone. Exercise can lower acetone levels, but when at rest, levels will come back up because you've ramped up metabolism, fat oxidation, and ketogenesis.

title: Ketogenesis and Insulin Suppression
content: Ketogenesis and fat mobilization for fuel is a function of insulin suppression. Exogenous ketones have many therapeutic applications, but it's important to understand what's going on in the liver, muscle, and brain when delivering exogenous ketones. Genetic factors can influence how someone responds to the ketogenic diet, including beta-oxidation defects, ACADs, CPT1 and CPT2 deficiency, hormone-sensitive lipase, and lipoprotein lipase.

title: Ketogenic diet for those with the APOE e4 allele
content: If you have one APOE e4 (and especially if you have two) the main thing to do is manage glucose and insulin. Important things important to track: Hemoglobin A1c is a really good indicator, Triglycerides, Your level of systemic inflammation using a high sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) test. You want these to all be as low as possible: glucose, hemoglobin A1C, triglycerides, insulin, hs-CRP. High blood pressure correlates with poor outcomes if you’re APOE e4 positive. Some people experience are huge spike in LDL when on a keto diet. If that is the case, a few suggestions would be… Limit saturated fat, Maybe take a low dose of a statin (a half a pill two times per week, like on Monday, Thursday), Rather than ketogenic, modify the diet to be higher protein, moderate fat, low carb diet may be with the fat source coming in the majority form of monounsaturated fat. Both sleep and exercise are important for prevention of Alzheimer’s disease, says Dom

title: Impact of long-term ketogenic diets on thyroid function
content: Dom has observed that some people see an see increase in their reverse T3 when on a keto diet (as well as when intermittent fasting). Certain micronutrients can help with maintaining thyroid function on a ketogenic diet. High selenium and high iodine foods (salt) are important. Dom’s favorites are sardines, liver, and Brazilian nuts. Dom also points out that the some people have high reverse T3 even when not calorie restricted. Which implies that the thyroid issue may have more to do with the suppression of insulin than it does the restriction of calories. It’s more common in women than men. This suppression of thyroid probably affects up to 40% of women, says Dom. But it’s hard to deconstruct what’s happening because some of them are over-exercising or calorie restricted or taking intermittent fasting a little too often. Dom suggests doing these things intermittently rather than continuously. And your body adapts to that state if you’re doing it all the time, so I believe it’s important to use it intermittently.

title: Low-carb and ketogenic diets for appetite control and weight management
content: Bob gained about 30 pounds in college. First, he tried just eating less, moving more, and found himself hungry and tired all the time.

title: Atkins and Keto Diet
content: Next, he tried the Atkins diet (meat, fish, fowl, eggs, cheese, leafy green vegetables) with no restriction on volume. He was surprised at how he was never too hungry and never too full. For the first time he found himself almost “forgetting to eat” at times. The keto diet lowers insulin and glucose to a point that allows you to then use your own body fat as fuel source (especially when you have fat to lose). In a way, you’re not really calorie restricted—“I almost think of it as you’re eucaloric, but more of your calories are coming from within.” Important: It might be better to give your body time to get into ketosis and/or adapt to using internal fat stores before dropping calories significantly.

title: Ketogenic Diet for Appetite Control and Weight Management
content: The ketogenic diet allows you to control your appetite instead of your appetite controlling you. Dieting by cutting calories but still eating refined carbs can lead to people becoming “neurotic about food” and can produce really disastrous and damaging eating behaviors. Low carb eating (not necessarily ketogenic) can really help to attenuate a lot of those cravings and is better for weight control in Dom’s opinion. “If you restore insulin sensitivity. . .you’re better able to access and burn fat, so that becomes a key feature.”

title: Ketogenic Diet and the Microbiome
content: Some people respond very well clinically with a carnivore diet, i.e., no soluble fiber or “fuel” for your intestinal bacteria. But fiber does have an important role in the microbiome. After eaten, soluble fiber breaks down to short-chain fatty acids (butyrates, acetate, propionate). The colonocytes (epithelial cell of the colon) then use that for fuel. Butyrates are also an epigenetic regulator in the form of histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor. Acetate and propionate also play an important role so that microbiome diversity is key. For Dom, personally, getting some amount of fiber is important. That being said, Dom says some people respond very well clinically to a diet that’s completely devoid of carbohydrates, such as in the case of those with small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO). But generally, he would not recommend to completely eliminate fiber all the time. Having some amount of fiber in the diet promotes microbiome diversity. But it doesn’t necessarily all have to come from plant foods. Some prebiotic fiber is really important long term for gut motility, microbiome diversity, and just for the overall microbiome.

title: Monounsaturated Fat versus Saturated Fat on the Ketogenic Diet
content: When first going onto a keto diet, he was following a mainly dairy fat based ketogenic diet and he noticed a skyrocketing of LDL. His triglycerides were also pretty high. Dom notes that he still eats a very high level of saturated fat. However, he has made an effort to add more monounsaturated fats. And that transition from saturated fat to more monounsaturated fat has given him a more favorable lipid profile. So for those seeing “abnormalities” in their lipid profile, that would be something Dom recommends. Dom’s approach is to simply limit his saturated fat intake to under 100 grams of saturated fat for one or two days a week.

title: Implications of Long-term Genetic and Epigenetic Adaptations to a Ketogenic Diet
content: A lot of unknowns on this topic. That said, there are clearly some epigenetic modifications going on with a long-term ketogenic diet which may have implications as it relates to genetic diseases.

title: Ketogenic Diet and Epigenetic Programs
content: The following indicators suggest that when on a keto diet you’re really activating epigenetic programs that are shifting your metabolism away from glycolytic to more fatty acid oxidation, ketogenic, ketogenesis, ketolysis, and ketone transport: Accelerating beta oxidation, Ketogenesis is likely upregulated over time, Ketolysis (breaking ketones down for energy in the mitochondria to make ATP) is upregulated, Ketone transport via the monocarboxylic acid transporters is upregulated over time, Increase in the proteins that are transcriptional translation of proteins that are associated with the MCTs.

title: Rise in LDL-C and LDL-P on a Ketogenic Diet
content: Why some people see a rise in LDL-C and LDL-P when on a ketogenic diet and what they can do about it. Dom admits this is a confusing topic which needs to be further investigated. The important role of LDL particles (LDL-P): It’s an important transport molecule for things like triglycerides and phospholipids, It also aids in growth and repair. Curious cases of high and low LDL. In the case of athletes, they tend to have a higher LDL when on keto because there’s a lot of turnover associated with the breakdown of protein and tissue, especially with hard training. In cancer patients, Dom has observed that cancer patients have a remarkably low LDL which is correlated with a high tumor burden. Some indication that having a low LDL predisposes you to cancer. What does LDL rise dramatically for some people? Dom says the reason for the skyrocketing LDL in the body is still unclear.

title: High LDL-P and Other Biomarkers on a Ketogenic Diet
content: Does a high LDL-p even matter when other markers improve? Dom is partly convinced that it’s not something to be really concerned about if it’s independently elevated. Especially when arguably more important biomarkers are unaffected or even improved with a ketogenic diet, such as: triglycerides down, HDL the same or slightly elevated, inflammation down, insulin down. Furthermore, it’s pretty common that in the first three months of a keto diet the LDL numbers will go up only to come down and normalize later on. “There just needs to be more research on this, but I’m not particularly concerned that the LDL is atherogenic.”

title: Ketogenic Diet and Familial Hypercholesterolemia
content: Should someone with familial hypercholesterolemia consider the ketogenic diet? The keto diet is “worth considering” for someone with FH, but Dom has some important advice.

title: Tips for Starting a Ketogenic Diet at 70+ Years Old
content: 1) Cut carbs gradually over 2-3 weeks instead of transitioning directly to a ketogenic diet. 2) Get comprehensive blood work done to ensure normal liver and kidney function. 3) Consider working with a ketogenic dietician for the first week or so to improve the learning curve.

title: Exogenous Ketones and Their Benefits
content: Exogenous ketones have numerous benefits for different medical conditions such as seizures, metabolic disorders, glucose metabolism disorders, neurological disorders, traumatic brain injury, enhanced wound healing, metabolic management of cancer, and appetite suppression for weight loss. Consuming exogenous ketones can lower glucose and help people achieve a GKI that we know could be therapeutic. Ketone salts are the most common form of exogenous ketones and are typically ingested orally.

title: Exogenous Ketones and Longevity
content: Stimulating a mild state of ketosis with exogenous ketones may be turning on genes and having signaling effects that are promoting a healthier metabolic state over time. Many researchers in this field adamantly believe that beta hydroxybutyrate is a pretty potent longevity molecule. Dom says he’s “waiting for the science” on that claim. However, if using exogenous ketones to optimize and preserve metabolic health then that can contribute to longevity.

title: Different Functions of D-β-hydroxybutyrate and L-β-hydroxybutyrate
content: A pure D beta-hydroxybutyrate ester was not very efficacious against oxygen toxicity seizures. The most robust effect in preventing oxygen toxicity seizures is a molecule that elevated D and L beta-hydroxybutyrate in the blood, and also acetoacetate all at the same level. Acetoacetate has a remarkable anti-convulsive effect. L-beta-hydroxybutyrate is more therapeutic… it could be a drug-like molecule that’s a drug that’s derived from an endogenously made molecule, but you’re delivering it and having drug-like effects. The D form may be more appropriate for an athlete.

title: Ketogenic Protocols for Management of Traumatic Brain Injuries
content: In the case of a traumatic brain injury, 80% of people with penetrating traumatic brain injuries have seizures. To prevent seizures, the ketogenic diet makes sense, but it’s hard to implement says Dom. A more sustainable concept would be a low carb diet with supplemental ketones (esters or salts). The goal would be to achieve a glucose ketone index of 1.0 to 2.0. This would lower inflammation and provide an alternative energy source to the brain.

title: Long Term Management of TBI: Salt or Ester?
content: The easiest way to do that is with a ketone ester. However, a ketone salt is more efficacious therapeutically. Dom says that the best approach is to mix the ketone salt with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT oil or MCT oil powder) in one-to-one combination. Exogenous ketones provide immediate substrate and the MCT molecule is stimulating ketones to be made in the liver. Whereas if you bolus ketone salts, you could be potentially reducing hepatic ketone production.

title: Comparing the Benefits and Therapeutic Uses of Various Medium-Chain Fatty Acids
content: Caprylic acid (aka C8, aka octanoic acid) is more ketogenic than capric acid (aka C10, aka decanoic acid). In self experiments, Dom sees about 20% more of an increase in ketones with C8 vs C10. But C10 may have anti-seizure benefits outside of the ketone production. Medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) are not metabolized like long-chain fatty acids (LCFA).

title: MCTs and Brain Energy
content: MCTs go right to the liver and stimulate beta oxidation of fatty acids very robustly. MCTs can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and offer a bigger advantage than C10. Coconut oil has lauric acid which may have immune-boosting effects. Mary Newport documented an improvement in Alzheimer’s disease with coconut oil. Ketone esters are 10 times more potent than coconut oil and can be used as a potential therapy for neurological diseases. A ketogenic metabolic therapy in the form of a ketone ester or just MCTs would be more efficacious as a means to energize the brain than a sugar-based metabolism or sugar-based intervention.

title: Caffeine and Brain Energy
content: Caffeine can enhance motivation and performance, but people can become addicted or habituated to caffeine. Steven Cunnane demonstrated that when you administer caffeine with MCTs, you convert more of those MCTs to ketones. MCT oil becomes more ketogenic when you consume it with caffeine because it stimulates the beta oxidation of fats. If you deliver caffeine with ketones, there’s a synergy that results in enhanced brain energy metabolism.

title: Ephedrine and Ketogenesis
content: Ephedrine is a very powerful stimulant that can stimulate ketogenesis. In a fasted state, taking a beta receptor agonist, which activates hormone-sensitive lipase, you can really boost your ketone levels.

title: Modafinil
content: Modafinil is a drug that can be used as a mild nootropic. It is a fairly moderate stimulant that has amphetamine-like effects, but it doesn’t trigger a pulse of dopamine like amphetamine. This is important because it doesn’t really have addictive properties like amphetamine. The literature also showed that you don’t habituate to it… meaning you can use it continuously use the same dose and you’ll get the same benefit. Dom speculates that it’s probably through catecholamines (e.g., dopamine) and maybe also through anti-gaba effects. It may be enhancing glutamatergic neurotransmitter activation or receptors, so maybe AMPA and NMDA receptor activation through glutamate.

title: Theanine and Phenibut
content: Theanine or phenibut is a phenylated GABA that is crossing the blood brain barrier. Dom calls it a mild CNS depressant where he feels less inhibited and the thoughts flow making him feel smarter and more creative. Sort of the opposite effect of a stimulant (which might cause too many neurons to fire and create analysis paralysis).

title: Supplemental use of testosterone, DHEA, and creatine for muscle growth and performance
content: Testosterone is an effective compound that will help grow muscle. If you are deficient in testosterone, Dom is in favor of supplementing with a doctor’s help. DHEA is a precursor that will break down into other hormones. Dom takes 25 milligrams of DHEA as a single dose upon waking up. An hour later, Dom will have a 20 or 25% increase in testosterone. Creatine has always been a staple for Dom. He takes it upon waking every morning. For Dom, it’s a noticeable effect in terms of his strength levels and also seems to give him a brain boost. Dom says everyone could benefit from about 3 grams of creatine daily. Dom says he does a loading phase of about 10 g per day for a week. This will put on 2 or 3 lbs of body weight. He will also be able to get an extra 2 reps or so on certain lifts.

title: Impact of fasted-state training on strength and performance
content: Dom once fasted for 7 days and then deadlifted over 500 lbs.

title: When does Dom feel strongest?
content: Dom feels strongest when fasted for about 8 to 16 hours as long as he’s well fed the days before. He tends to always get his PRs when he 8-16 hours fasted coming of 2 days of a calorie surplus.

title: Pushing vs. pressing in a fasted state
content: "I wouldn’t try benching because I do think you might be a little bit dehydrated from depleting glycogen." "That cellular leverage you have when you’re in a fed state, it’s going to transfer to pressing exercises, whereas pulling exercises not so much." "I do feel better, lighter on my feet, and my CNS can just fire and recruit more muscle, if I’m in that fasted or semi-fasted state doing things like squats and deadlifts. and pull ups, too."

title: Stacking exogenous ketones with MCTs for optimal effectiveness
content: BHB and MCT is a stack that you’d want to use if you’re considering exogenous ketones. Ketones and/or MCT can be stacked with caffeine.

title: Thoughts on branched-chain amino acid (BCAAs) and essential amino acid (EAA) supplements
content: Dom used BCAAs for years and more recently was using EAAS. However, he generally feels they unnecessary in most cases. They may have benefit for people in a calorie restricted state and if you use them intra-workout. Someone who is a bit older (65+) may benefit because you become anabolic resistant with age. Total muscle mass is a function of protein breakdown and anabolic activity. You’re slowing muscle degradation and probably stimulating mTOR in skeletal muscle (if the leucine content is high enough).

title: Are BCAAs helpful for muscle preservation during prolonged fasting?
content: Dom says the results would be minimal, if any. BCAAs also have calories, so it would be sort of like eating egg whites. "You’d probably see an effect with skeletal muscle protein synthesis soon after you took it, but I think it kind of all balances out in time."

title: Current Supplements Dom uses
content: Creatine monohydrate, Alpha Lipoic Acid, CoQ10, MSM, Glucosamine, Chondroitin.

title: Dom's Macro Tracking App
content: Dom has been trying out the Carbon – Smart Diet Coach app, which was developed by a natural bodybuilder named Layne Norton. Dom really likes it and recommends using the app for the learning experience. He realized he’s eating about 10-20% more calories than he estimated, but his weight has stayed the same after 8 days. His baseline calorie needs are really 4,000 per day. He was also eating more carbs than he thought but he was still staying in ketosis.

title: Micronutrients on a Ketogenic Diet
content: Dom doesn’t worry about getting enough micronutrients while on a ketogenic diet. He believes you can get all the micronutrients you really need with foods like liver, fish, egg yolks, and sardines. There may be some benefits from plants, but he doesn't think it's absolutely necessary.

title: Ideal Macros for Staying in Ketosis While Getting Enough Protein for Strength Training
content: Dom believes that your macro breakdown to remain in ketosis depends on the individual. The “lowest fat macro percent for staying ketosis” depends on your total calorie intake. On high calorie days, Dom can be at 125 grams of carbs (a third being fiber) and stay in ketosis. Carbs being 10-15% of this macros. Yet, his ketones are anywhere between 1.2 and 2.2 throughout the day. Dom gets about 400 grams of fat per day and 120 g of protein on the lowest days. He usually stays in the 1.5 grams per kilogram but likes to pulse his protein once or twice a week up to 200 grams to help with recovery after some harder training days.

title: Pros, Cons, and Ideal Macros of One Meal a Day
content: Dom believes that one meal a day is a very effective way to produce a calorie deficit for those needing to lose weight. However, it would be difficult for an athlete to get all calorie and macro needs into one meal. Dom does do OMAD often but will every once in a while. His one meal might be a ribeye, fatty salad with olive oil and feta, ~80 grams of protein, ~100 grams of fat, and ~30 grams of fibrous carbohydrates, so about ~1500 calories. He might also sneak in his favorite keto chocolate mousse for dessert. A narrow eating window could also enhance insulin sensitivity.

title: Dom's Take on Carb Backloading
content: Dom eats all his carbs right with dinner and after dinner snacks. He sort of does carb backloading.

title: Advantages to keeping SOME carbohydrates in the diet
content: Taking in 50 to 100 grams of carbs per day of slow-burning carbohydrates is enough to aid in repair (especially if you’re working out). It will also prevent you from completely suppressing pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDH). It will allow you to keep insulin sensitivity high with keeping the PDH pathway open. For Dom, carbs consists of fibrous carbs, avocado, fruits like blueberries, grapefruits, nectarine, Nuts, Dark chocolate (which he has every night). For Dom, that ends up at 70 to 100 grams of carbs.

title: Total carb restriction
content: With prolonged total carb restriction, you will produce a physiological glucose/carbohydrate intolerance. And if you go back to eating carbs, you’re going to have a hyper-insulin response and hyperglycemia. Whereas just keeping a little bit of carbohydrates in, you can maintain your carbohydrate tolerance.

title: Carb backloading concept
content: Kiefer came up with the idea of carb backloading. It basically looks like… Breakfast and lunch is low-carb/keto. Exercise later in the day or the evening, and that’s when you would ramp up the carbohydrates. Kiefer’s rationale: You’re more insulin sensitive in the morning and a little more insulin resistant at night (just general circadian rhythm). Therefore, you may be more susceptible to storing your energy as fat when you’re more insulin sensitive in the morning. So you basically ride out the overnight fast, which increases fat oxidation, keep carbs at a minimum. Then you train and exercise and eat the carbs right after your exercise. The thought is that after a hard workout you’d partition more glucose to the muscles and less to fat, in part because of the non-insulin mediated glucose uptake, and in part because the fat cells may be a little more insulin resistant at night. Furthermore, the carbs Kiefer suggested eating were higher glycemic (e.g., cherry turnovers) which would spike insulin and spike the growth after a workout.

title: Dom’s take on “carb up” days for ketogenic dieters
content: Dom doesn’t do “carb up” days. Rather, he will increase his total calories by about 25% a couple days a week. But he just eats more of the same foods he already eats. Generally, this means a bit more protein around his heavy training days. When “carbing up” in the past, it would trigger a roller coaster in energy levels for Dom. “I get the same effect without the hormonal roller coaster.”

title: Beware if you have addictive eating behaviors
content: Some people are proponents of carb up day and cheat days. But Bob points out that for people who are addicted to bad foods, this can backfire. Dr. Steve Phinney describes something called “intrusive thoughts of hunger” where a person might have a voice in their head that says, “Wouldn’t you like to have that donut?”

title: PET scans showing addictive behavior
content: PET scans of the brain of people eating meals show that obese people leave “no doubt that the obese person is activating the same mechanisms of addiction with this kind of feeding”

title: Dom’s thoughts on the carnivore diet and the paleolithic ketogenic diet
content: A group in Hungary called Paleomedicina is studying the paleolithic ketogenic diet (similar to the carnivore diet). It’s shown to be pretty effective for managing a number of things, especially autoimmune disorders and gut health. They’ve been using the diet to type 1 diabetes and argue that they may be actually restoring some of the insulin function with the diet (at least when looking at C-peptide). Dom thinks it could work really well for ultrarunners. Keto diet promotes many adaptations that can enhance recovery from the crazy workouts. When first starting a ketogenic diet, you’re likely to experience a negative hit to your physiological, cognitive, and even immunological performance because it’s a stress to your body.

title: Keto Adaptation
content: The magnitude of the negative consequences of keto adaptation will depend on the individual. Endurance athletes may already be somewhat keto adapted because there’s post-exercise ketosis. The normal everyday person probably will go through a time of discomfort during the adaptation period. Phinney and Volek, in The Art and Science of Low Carbohydrate Performance, discuss keto adaptation could be weeks to months. Dom thinks you’re not really getting full adaptation until about six months. The best way to fully adapt is to train while in the state of ketosis—to put your body under extreme stress in that physiological state.

title: Fasted-state elevation in growth hormone and its impact on training
content: GH elevation occurs during a fast. But Dom is not convinced it gives a training advantage or helps with muscle gain. There are advantages to training in a fasted state. The elevation in growth hormone is just a consequence of our physiology and to liberate more fat for energy through the lipolytic effect. It may have an anti catabolic effect—so enhancing lipolysis may be sparing muscle to some extent. Growth hormone is anabolic to some extent…but growth hormone will cause an increase in tissue of all your organs too. Rather, he’s focused on being in an optimal physiological state for training—fully fed the prior day, glycogen is up, and he’s well rested. He then goes into the workout fasted between 8 and 16 hours and that’s when he has his best workouts and when he most often hits his personal records.

title: Is it possible to build muscle on a ketogenic diet?
content: The key thing to remember is that you’re probably going to be a little bit dehydrated which means your blood volume is down and it’ll be harder to get a pump and maintain a high workout intensity. Dom is now doing mostly maintenance with no aspirations to be any bigger or heavier. He’s noticed that if he stops doing heavy compound lifts (deadlifts, squats, etc.) he will lose some weight. His workout for maintenance are really quick. Dom says he would need to double or triple his training volume in order to add muscle mass. Two or three hours a week of really intense, structured training. But most important in adding mass happens with nutrition. Dom spikes protein two or three times a week if he’s trying to gain and does so to correlate with recovery from heavier workouts. So adding muscle on a keto diet is “definitely possible”.

title: Dom's Cardio Exercise
content: Dom doesn’t do deliberate/traditional cardio exercises. He does a lot of walking, typically 30 minutes with the dogs after a meal. He will do high rep deadlifts 315 lbs for 60 seconds, 3 rounds. He tends to get his “cardio” in by doing work around his property, e.g., tree cutting and lifting them into a chipper.

title: Protocols for Hard Training Recovery
content: Dom uses the Joovv Elite red light system 2 or 3 times per week after a heavy lift. He does dead hangs every day. He will sometimes do weighted hangs too. Nutritionally, he will bump up protein in order to boost calories by about 25%. He feels it’s important to just take a walk after big meals.

title: Dom's Personal Approach to Fasting, Time-Restricted Eating, and Sleep
content: Dom doesn’t fast every day. Maybe 2 or 3 times a week he will do some time-restricted feeding. On days when he is planning to train in the evening, he makes sure to have breakfast otherwise he can’t seem to get in all the calories he needs post-workout without disrupting his sleep. Dom prioritizes his sleep. Early bedtime and has a sleep routine. He tracks it with Oura Ring and Fitbit Inspire.

title: People, Books, and Other Resources That Shaped Dom’s Training and Nutrition
content: In Dom’s early days, he was influenced by The New Encyclopedia of Modern Bodybuilding by Arnold Schwarzenegger, Dorian Yates, Mike Mentzer, and Ed Coan and his powerlifting templates (book). In the 2000s, he was influenced by Skip Lacour and Layne Norton. Now, Dom’s more focused on longevity and is influenced by Doug McGuff (IHMC podcast, lecture) and Art De Vany (IHMC talks).

title: Book Title
content: Hardcore Bodybuilding: A Scientific Approach

title: Author
content: Fred Hatfield aka Dr. Squat
